results.justification: The document explicitly states the research focus on team formation and its challenges, outlining the goal of exploring design considerations for positive collaborative outcomes. It also mentions the use of a priority algorithm.
Section 3 details the priority algorithm with pseudocode (Algorithm 1) and a schematic (Figure 1), providing a step-by-step description of its operation. Section 4 describes the evaluation framework.
The document mentions using real class data but does not provide a link or mention where the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.
The document states data collection involved student surveys and acknowledges potential privacy concerns implicitly by not sharing the raw data.

While the document describes the characteristics of the student data (e.g., gender distribution, GPA), it lacks a detailed data dictionary or codebook explaining all variables and preprocessing steps.

The document states data was collected from university classes in 2022 and 2023, including student surveys eliciting background information. It also details the types of information collected (e.g., timeslot availability, grades).
The document states: "The Algorithms repository is available at https://github.com/Teamable-Analytics/algorithms."
Code is shared, so justification is not needed.
The document does not explicitly mention whether code for data preparation is shared, only that the algorithms repository is available.
The document describes the use of statistical measures like cosine difference, Gini-Simpson index, and the definition of the objective function with weighted scores.
The document reports metrics like project coverage, common times, intra-heterogeneity, inter-homogeneity, and solo status, which can be interpreted as effect sizes or measures of performance.
The document primarily focuses on quantitative analysis and lacks in-depth subjective context or interpretation beyond the statistical results.
The results are presented in tables (e.g., Table 1, Table 2) and figures (e.g., Figure 3, Figure 4, Figure 5, Figure 6, Figure 7, Figure 8), with clear descriptions of the findings.
Section 6.1 discusses limitations, including the need for more comparison algorithms and testing on more student distributions. The document also acknowledges potential biases.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
